instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
screen is covered by wiggly lines across it and the screen is turning off and on but there is no backlight, i was checking with a light.  i tested multiple times and more than half the time the wiggly lines only flashes once and then the screen goes back to blank and the light can shine through.  i changed the <CHIP>U3990</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> because they had some nasty stuff on them.  

<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32v 

<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - o volts

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 12.54v 

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.12v

L9000- 0 volts

<CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR> o volts

<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 0 volts  

any ideas? 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
If your LVDS connector, cable and screen are all fine then you can probably assume the missing backlight is down to bad joints under <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>. Gmux will probably need reballing. what does <SIGNAL>LVDS_BKL_PWM_RC</SIGNAL> measure? 

Was it liquid damaged? based on the 'nasty stuff' you may also want to check around <CHIP>U9320</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9370</CHIP> for corrosion or damaged traces.

Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> if your screen flashes up and then disappears. Pictures could be useful.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
wow okay so not sure if this board fucked the screen up but i was about to run some test on the board i fixed last night with backlight issues and now that board has no data or backlight.... no voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> - o volts, <CAPACITOR>C9002</CAPACITOR> o volts. did the board i was testing fuck the screen up that could have fucked the board up? Really bummed out right now haha. now i''m guessing my test screen is fried but im not willing to test in on a good working board after my fixed board from last night went out on it without even working at all. any ideas? suggestions?

As for the board im working on i will look into the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>LVDS_BKL_PWM_RC</SIGNAL> - 0 volts
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>- 3.32 volts

yes liquid seemd like soda.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
okay so i found the <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> had pins 3 and 2 touching. now i have  0 volts on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> mainly i have no <SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> and i also have no data. i uc the board and now it does not show any wiggly lines anymore. 

0 volts <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> 0 volts

<SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_BKL</SIGNAL> - 0 volts

is okay to heat the gmux up to give it a reflow?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message: Its not detecting the screen. try known good lcd or the lvds connector

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
dont heat up the gmux. 99% of the time the edge bonding stuff will mess it all up. gota be reballed unless you can get the edge bonding of cleanly.

and from this point follow dukes instructions anyway, i completely missed that its missing voltage at L9000

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
okay good to know thanks for that info ALB.  Not sure where dukes instructions are unless you just confused philipc with duke.  either way i will look into the lvds connector.  I know the screen is good because i just tested a few other board on it that are working.  

checked out the lvds connector pin 14 was not connecting,  fixed that but still no change.  i check the lvds connector out really good nothing other than pin 14 seemed to be messed up. 

on the <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> i get power on pins 3 and 4 and nothing on pins 1,2,5,6  what would cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
Yes, i was getting confused. Duke needs an easily recognisable avatar or something ;) 

You need a signal on pins 5 and 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>, that creates a voltage divider out of <RESISTOR>R9808</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9809</RESISTOR>. Whats the resistance between pins 3 and 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR>?

Its more likely that youre looking at the complete wrong area though. 
Measure for power on L9560, L8920 and L7530.
My bet is you are missing a GPU rail causing no display.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
haha yeah agreed.

okay i only have a signal on pin 2, and pin 5 <SIGNAL>LCD_BKTL_EN</SIGNAL> is not there.

res between <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR> pins 3 and 4 = 305.6K. in diode mode gives me nothing.

l9560 = 1.37v

l8920 = .93v

l7530 = 1.15v

Thanks you tons for the help you probably have no idea how much it means to me! :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
Wait, Does this board chime? work on external.ect? 
Whats the voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
appears to have no chime,  my external connector seems to be broken, Tested it on a few other computers with no luck. so i cannot confirm if it is working on external or not.  will order a new one.  

USB drive is working.

0.8V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
This is becoming a pain in the arse.

0.8V on this board would suggest it chimes.
Do a PRAM reset and see if it chimes.
Rule out bad audio by removing ram and seeing if it beeps.
We really need to know if this is posting, if it is, youre on the lines of a bad gpu or a bad gmux.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message: Yes getting chime. my guess is bad gmux. is there an easy way to test this besides  reball/swapping it out with another one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message: not really. Gmux's very rarely fail though, just like SMC's they are programmed for boards as well so youd need to pull for a 2850 board. please do check the entire board under a microscope and check out every little trace/probe point/sign of corrosion before wasting your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
also great to know! i do have quite a few 2850 donor board to pull from. i guess i also wouldn't be surprised to find something missing on the board. this board came in pretty bad liquid damaged and not sure what they did to the thing but it had the cdrom connector torn off the board, and some knocked off parts and the backlight fuse was fried so im guessing there is also a good chance of a damage trace/probe point.  i will look the board over really good a few more times for anything missing, or damaged traces/probe points

Thanks again for all the help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message: Good luck, at this point im going to leave it to duke and the rest of the forum. could well be a knocked of component somewhere but without it in front of me i cant really dig any deeper.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight data issue
threads.message:
checking out around the gpu and found about 3 or 4 solder balls stuck to the edge bonding so i think that is the obvious culprit right there.  unfortunately i do not have a BGA rework station at this time to fix this. But at least we figured it out.  
Many thanks, Cheers Mate!
